Abstract 26 Er3+/Yb3+ co-doped YF3 samples with uniform rice-like, two-dimension (2D) hexagonal 27 nano-architectures and truncated octahedral micro-crystals were synthesized through a one-step 28 hydrothermal method, and their possible growth mechanisms were also proposed. Upon 980 nm 29 excitation, the up-conversion (UC) emitting color of samples was finely modulated from yellow to 30 pure green with increasing the particle size, which was interpreted in terms of non-radiative 31 process and surface effect. Thermometric capabilities of samples with different morphologies were 32 evaluated based on the fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR) of 2H11/2 and 4S3/2 levels through 33 temperature-dependent UC spectra, and the optimal absolute sensitivities of samples were all 34 approached to about 0.0026 K-1 at 490 K. The potentiality of rice-like nano-crystals for 35 temperature detection in sub-tissue was demonstrated by ex vivo experiments. Results display that 36 the sensitivity of YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ nano/micro-crystals is independent of morphologies and sizes, 37 which exploit an effective avenue for developing UC-based thermometers in sub-tissue with stable 38 sensitivity. 39 40
Keywords: Up-conversion; Nano/Micro-crystals; Morphology; Thermometry; Biological 41 sensing. 42 43

sections.heading: 1. Introduction 44
sections.text:
Real-time temperature detection with high accuracy and spatial resolution is urgently desired for 45 scientific research, industrial manufacturing and life activity [1-3]. Comparing with conventional 46 contact temperature sensors, fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR) technique based on up-conversion 47 nano/microparticles (UCNPs/UCMPs), which is implemented by monitoring the intensity ratio of 48 thermo-responsive UC emission lines from two thermally coupled levels (TCLs) at different 49 temperature, has been considered as a promising thermal-sensing method due to its noninvasive 50 operation, high spatial and thermal resolution, self-reference and tunable size features [4, 5]. 51 Generally, the energy separation between two TCLs falls in the range of 200~2000 cm-1 to avoid 52 serious overlapping of the two emission bands and allow the upper energy level to have sufficient 53 population, which decides the scope of temperature detection. Through analyzing distributions of 54
energy levels, TCLs can be found in several lanthanide ions such as Er3+, Ho3+, Tm3+, Nd3+, Dy3+ 55 and so on. Among these ions, Er3+ ion is the most representative activator for ratiometric 56 luminescence thermometers (RLTs) due to its eye-sensitive green emitting and appropriate energy 57
gap (≈ 800 cm-1) between energy levels 4S3/2 and 2H11/2, and Yb 3+ ion is usually combined used as 58 a sensitizer to enhance the UC intensity and suppress deviation of RLTs benefiting from its 59 sufficient absorption cross section near 980 nm [6-11]. 60 Near-infrared (NIR) light excitation endows UCNPs/UCMPs-based RLTs great potential in 61 biological application because of its little damage to biological tissues, high signal to noise ratio, 62 deep penetration depth and minimized background auto-luminescence, making it a reliable 63 candidate for subcutaneous and intracellular sensing. Simultaneously, biocompatible 64 UCNPs/UCMPs with sub-tissue thermal sensing and bio-imaging bi-function have been also 65 explored as powerful tools for tissular thermo-kinetic studies in vivo experiments, early diagnosis, 66 prevention of overheating during photothermal therapy (PTT), etc [12-15]. Recently, a new type of 67 highly sensitive luminescent thermometer was reported by L. Marciniak et al. through the 68 emission intensity ratio of temperature dependent d-d Cr3+ transitions to f-f Nd3+ transitions using 69 downshifting energy transfer from Cr3+ to Nd3+. The best performance for luminescent 70 thermometers applied in biology could be achieved for their absorbing and emitting in the region 71 of optical window of biological tissues, which provides an excellent strategy to significantly 72 deepen light penetration depth and enhance the thermal sensitivity [16-18]. Though remarkable 73 progress has been achieved recently on biological thermometry, great efforts are dedicated to 74 enhancing and optimizing the sensor resolution and sensitivity that accurately determines the 75 minimum temperature variations. As well-known, particle size and morphology exert significant 76 impact on luminescent and heating property, but its effect on sensor sensitivity remains an open 77 question, which greatly impede the development of FIR-based thermometer in biology [19-23]. 78 Temperature sensors at micro/nano-scale are necessarily required for thermometry in biology, 79 and various controllable synthetic strategies have been employed to prepare highly dispersed 80 inorganic nano/micro-crystals. Solution-based hydrothermal method is a frequently-used approach 81 to control the size, morphology and chemical homogeneity of samples through tuning 82 experimental conditions, which has been extensively employed to tailor the fluorides and complex 83 oxides [24-27]. As a member of the lanthanide fluorides, yttrium fluoride (YF3) is an ideal host 84
candidate for UC-based RLTs owing to its low phonon energy and wide band gap [28-30]. Here, 85 Er3+/Yb3+ ion pair doped YF3 nano/micro-thermometers with precisely controlled morphology 86 were synthesized by hydrothermal procedure through adjusting the fluorine sources and the 87 dosage of NH4F without any surfactants assistance. Rice-like, 2D hexagonal plate-like and 88 truncated octahedral sample particles were obtained, and their possible growth mechanism was 89 proposed. Strikingly, the effect of architectures and size distributions on UC emission color, 90 heating ability and thermometric sensitivity was also elaborately explored, and the temperature 91 detection capability of rice-like UCNPs in sub-tissue was also assessed by ex vivo experiments. 92

sections.heading: 2.1. Sample preparation. 94
sections.text:
1%Er3+-5%Yb3+ co-doped YF3 samples were synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method using 95 high purity Ln2O3 (Ln = Yb, Er, Y) (99.99%, Shanghai Yuelong Nonferrous Metals Ltd.) and 96 analytical reagent (A.R.) NH4F or NaBF4 as raw materials. In a typical experiment, appropriate 97 quantity of Ln2O3 was first dissolved in diluted HNO3 with constant stirring until excessive nitric 98 acid was evaporated, then a certain volume of de-ionized water was introduced to form lanthanide 99 nitrates solution. Subsequently, the precursor solution (total 70 mL) was obtained after dissolving 100 the calculated quantity of fluorine source (NH4F or NaBF4) into the nitrates solution under 101 continuous stirring for 1 h (pH = 2), which was transferred and sealed into a 100 mL Teflon-lined 102 stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 180 °C for 24 h. Finally, the white precipitates were 103 separated by centrifugation after washing three times with de-ionized water and ethanol, and 104 further dried at 70 °C for 24 h in air to get the final products. 105
2.2. Measurements and characterization. 106 The crystalline phases were identified on a Rigaku-Dmax 3C powder X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku 107 Corp, Tokyo, Japan) with Cu-Kα (λ = 1.54056 Å) radiation in the range of 10o ~ 60 o, and the 108 surface-covered functional groups were examined by an Bruker EQUINOX55 Fourier transform 109 infrared (FTIR) spectrometer (Germany). A Hitachi SU-8010 field emission scanning electron 110 microscope (FE-SEM) and FEI TF-20 transmission electron microscope (TEM, accelerating 111 voltage = 200 kV) were employed to investigate the microcosmic structures of samples. The 112 temperature dependent up-conversion (UC) spectra (260-490 K) were collected using an Edinburgh 113
FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with an external 980 nm semiconductor laser, an 114 Oxford OptistatDN2 nitrogen cryogenics and CTI-Cryogenics temperature controlling system. 115 Single particle UC luminescent properties of samples were performed on a BX43-OLYMPUS 116 microscope with a 976 nm semiconductor laser. The temperature data in ex vivo experiments and 117 thermal-images were obtained using an InfReC R500 (Nippon electronic company, Japan) infrared 118 thermal camera. 119
3. Results and discussion 120
3.1. Morphological engineering of samples. 121 Effects of fluorine sources: Different dissoluble fluorides have been extensively employed as 122 fluorine sources in the hydrothermal method to tailor the size and shape of lanthanide fluorides, 123 implying that the microcosmic structures of final samples highly depend on the initial fluorine 124 sources [25, 26]. Figure S1(a) displays the XRD patterns of YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ products using the 125 stoichiometric amounts of NaBF4 and NH4F as fluorine sources, respectively. All diffraction peaks 126 can be readily indexed to a pure orthorhombic-phased YF3 (JCPDS No. 74-0911) with Pnma (62) 127 space group and no any impurity peaks could be detected, suggesting that different fluorine 128 sources hardly affect the phase composition of products in present experiments. In comparison 129 with NH4F-prepared samples, the broader full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of main peak 130 (111) for products synthesized using NaBF4, as presented in Figure S1(b), indicates a smaller 131 particle size using NaBF4 as fluorine source according to the Scherrer equation [31]. The 132 representative SEM and TEM images of YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ particles (Figure 1) further verified the 133 tremendous difference in morphology and size of samples synthesized using NaBF4 and NH4F as 134 fluorine source. When NaBF4 was employed, a bunch of regular and well-defined rice-like 135 nanoparticles with uniform size of 70 nm in length and 40 nm in width were clearly observed in 136 Figure 1a and b. The corresponding high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) 137 pattern taken with the electron beam perpendicular to the edge of an individual nanoparticle 138 (Figure 1c) disclosed that the lattice interplanar spacing was about 3.67 Å, corresponding to the 139 d-spacing values of the (101) planes of YF3 crystal. Upon substituting NaBF4 with NH4F as 140 fluorine source, the products are mainly composed of two-dimensional nanoplates with hexagonal 141 shape (250 nm in average length). Those 2D plates lie parallel to the silicon substrate and no any 142
stands vertically due to extremely thin in thickness, and the overlap of the edges could be evidently 143 observed, as displayed in Figure 1d and e. The HR-TEM image performed on the edge of a single 144 nanoplate (Figure 1f) indicates well-resolved interplanar spacing of 3.16 Å, corresponding to the 145 (111) crystal face. These results also indicated that the particle size of samples using NH4F is 146 larger than that of sample synthesized using NaBF4, which was consistent with XRD data. 147 Above results suggest that the fluorine sources exert great influence on the formation of 148 various architectures, and the possible growth processes for the YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ products 149 synthesized using NaBF4 or NH4F were proposed and displayed in Figure 1g. When introducing 150 NaBF4 as fluorine source, the anions F - were slowly released through the hydroxylation process of 151
NaBF4 (BF4 - + 3H2O ↔ F - + 3HF + H3BO3). Thus, the initial precursor solution was transparent 152 and no precipitation formed under vigorous stirring due to the slow release rate of fluorine anion. 153 Whereas the white fluoride precipitation appeared with the addition of NH4F before hydrothermal 154 process because free F- in solution was immediately released from NH4F and then reacted with 155 Ln3+ to form fluoride nuclei [26]. Different release rate of F- from NaBF4 and NH4F in solution 156 greatly affected the nucleation rate and crystal growth process, directly resulting in the various 157 morphologies of the final products. Additionally, the cations from fluorine sources (Na+ or NH4 +) 158 are also closely related to the formation of specific morphologies through selectively absorbing on 159 different crystal facets of the growing crystal seeds and changing the surface energy of specific 160 facets [32]. In present system, the growth rates along different crystallographic orientations using 161 NaBF4 or NH4F as F - source are distinctly different due to the different ionic radius of Na+ and 162
NH4 +, consequently leading to the formation of various architectures of YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ particles. 163 Effect of the NH4F dosage: As well-known, molar ratio of the original reagents would affect the 164 morphology of the final products during the hydrothermal process. Aiming at shedding light on 165 the role of NH4F dosage, a series of controlled experiments were carried out with varying ratios of 166
NH4F to Ln 3+ from 3 to 4.1. XRD patterns of YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ products as a function of NH4F to 167 Ln3+ ratio were illuminated in Figure S2, in which pure orthorhombic YF3 could be obtained as the 168 ratio ranging from 3 to 3.5. However, several characteristic peaks attributed to the impurity phase 169 of (NH4)2Ln5F17 were observed and became stronger with further increasing ratios of NH4F to 170 Ln3+ from 3.5 to 4.1. Surprisingly, the impurity peaks disappeared after heating the sample 171 (NH4F/Ln 3+ = 3.8) at 600 °C for 1 h in air through the pyrolysis reaction: (NH4)2Ln5F17 → 5LnF3 + 172
2NH3↑ + 2HF↑, further confirming that the secondary phase is (NH4)2Ln5F17 caused by the excess 173 NH4F. The representative SEM micrographs of corresponding products with different NH4F/Ln 3+ 174 ratios were presented in Figure 2 to detect the evolution of morphology and particle size. As 175 increasing NH4F/Ln 3+ ratio from 3.2 to 3.5, the final products transferred to uniform and 176 mono-dispersed truncated octahedra with extremely smooth surfaces (Figure 2b) from the mixture 177 of irregular stone-like particles and imperfect truncated octahedra (Figure 2a, e). The SEM 178 observation on a single and intact truncated octahedron from different angles (Figure 2f) evidently 179 reveals that the average side length is appropriately 1.5 µm. However, with further rising the 180 dosage of NH4F, the average side length truncated octahedral particle kept increasing to about 2 181 and 8 µm for NH4F/Ln 3+ = 3.8 and 4.1, simultaneously more and more (NH4)2RE5F17 182 nanoparticles emerged and attached on the surfaces of truncated octahedra, as displayed in Figure 183 2(c, g) and (d, h). Interestingly, most of those nanoparticles disappeared after calcination treatment 184 at 600 °C for 1 h in air and no other significant changes were observed (Figure S3), which is 185 identical with XRD results. SEM results indicate that highly dispersed and uniform truncated 186 octahedral micro-structure could be obtained at the ratio of NH4F/Ln 3+ = 3.5, and the top and side 187 views of truncated octahedra were shown in Figure 2(i, j). The obvious dark/bright contrast 188 between the center and edge part in the TEM images further confirms the truncated octahedral 189 architectural prototype. Clear lattice fringe with well-resolved interplanar distance (3.21 Å) 190 corresponding to the (111) plane of YF3 crystal could be clearly observed from the HR-TEM 191 image (Figure 2k) recorded at the circle marked area. It can be inferred that a truncated octahedron 192 is consist of two rhombic crystal facets {010} and eight energetically equivalent trapeziform 193 planes {111}, as disclosed in Figure 2l. 194 As schematically depicted in Figure 2i, when more NH4F were introduced into the system, the 195 {010} and {111} crystallographic crystal facets of starting crystal nucleus could be capped by 196 more NH4 + and then significantly suppress the relative growth rates along those planes, resulting 197 in the growing process from 2D hexagonal nanoplates through bigger stone-like particles to 198 regular truncated octahedral microparticles. On the other hand, the size of truncated octahedrons 199 would keep growing and secondary phase of (NH4)2RE5F17 could be generated with the further 200 increase of NH4F dosage. Above contrast experimental results demonstrate that the molar ratio of 201 NH4F to Ln 3+ in the initial solution plays an essential role in the conversion process from 2D 202
hexagonal nanoplates to truncated octahedral micro-crystals. 203 Possible formation mechanism of truncated octahedra: The crystallization process in the 204 hydrothermal reaction is hard to be real-time observed, which could be speculated through 205 analyzing the crystal phase and morphology of samples under different reaction time periods [33]. 206 In an attempt to disclose the growth mechanism of truncated octahedral YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ 207 micro-products (NH4F/Ln 3+ = 3.5), the time-dependent XRD analysis and corresponding 208 morphology evolution were monitored. Before hydrothermal process, the white precipitations in 209 initial solution were mainly composed of irregular and aggregated nanoparticles (Figure 3a), 210 which are assigned to the mixture of YF3 and (NH4)Ln3F10 according to its XRD pattern (Figure 211 S4). At the beginning of hydrothermal reaction for about 1h, a little of imperfect truncated 212 octahedral crystals with side lengths of about 500 nm emerged together with numerous 213 nanoparticles-aggregated spheroids (Figure 3b), and their composition remained similar with that 214 of initial white precipitation. After reacting for 6 and 12 h (Figure 3c, d), irregular nanoparticles 215 completely vanished and evolved to mono-disperse and defective truncated octahedral rudiment 216 with several holes and mean lengths of appropriately 600 and 750 nm. The well-dispersed and 217 fully-developed truncated octahedral shape appeared with 1.5 µm edge length and highly smooth 218 surfaces as proceeding to 24 h (Figure 3e), but perfect truncated octahedral micro-particles trend 219 to shrinkage with rough facets and gradually deviate from the well-defined structure as further 220 prolonging the reaction time to 36 h. The corresponding XRD patterns indicate that the pure 221 orthorhombic phase YF3 could be obtained after reacting for 6 h. Therefore, the optimal synthesize 222 parameters for mono-dispersed and perfect truncated octahedral YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ micro-crystals are 223 180 °C for 24 h at the ratio of NH4F/Ln 3+ = 3.5. 224 Inspired by aforementioned time-dependent experimental results, a receivable growth 225 mechanism and formation process of truncated octahedral was elaborately elucidated and depicted 226 in Figure 3g. At the early reaction stage, the amorphous precipitations firstly crystallized into 227 metastable (NH4)Y3F10 phase, then the numerous irregular nanoparticles with large surface energy 228 aggregated rapidly to form bigger quasi-spheres through a thermodynamics-driven spontaneous 229 process. Under an acidic hydrothermal interaction environment with high temperature and high 230 pressure, stable YF3 was gradually transformed from metastable (NH4)Ln3F10 through reacting 231
with free H+ ions: (NH4)Ln3F10 + H+ →NH4 + + HF + 3LnF3. Driven by the minimization of the 232
surface energy, these small quasi-spheres severing as building blocks dissolved and re-crystallized 233 to YF3 crystal seeds. Simultaneously, newly released and dominated NH4 + ions selectively 234 absorbed on the crystal facets {010} and {111} of growing YF3 nucleus to inhibit the growth rate 235 along vertical crystallographic orientations of these crystal facets, leading to the formation of 236 imperfect truncated octahedra with holes and defects. Ultimately, the defective products gradually 237 grew by combining with small crystal seeds and underwent a structural modification to smooth 238 their surfaces through an Ostwald ripening process, resulting in the realization of mono-disperse 239 and perfect truncated octahedral YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ micro-crystals. 240 3.2. Up-conversion luminescent properties. 241 Since the microcosmic architectures and size distribution of YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ samples were totally 242 different, their effects on UC emission were demonstrated and presented in Figure 4. Under 980 243 nm laser excitation, the UC emission spectra of rice-like, 2D hexagonal and truncated octahedral 244 products mainly consist of two green emission bands peaked at 524 and 538 nm and a red 245
emission band centered at 660 nm, corresponding to the 2H11/2, 4S3/2 → 4I15/2 and 4F9/2 → 4I15/2 246 intrinsic transitions of Er3+ ion, respectively. Intriguingly, different morphologies make no obvious 247 influence on the shape and position of emission bands, while the UC emission intensities and red 248 to green ratios (R/G ratio) are extremely affected. Observed from the line chart and histograms 249 (Figure 4b), the overall integrated emission intensity continuously increases while the R/G ratio 250 sharply decreases from 1.05 (rice-like particle) through 0.41 (2D hexagonal plate) to 0.30 251 (truncated octahedron), resulting in the modulation of visible emission color from yellow through 252 yellowish green to pure green (inset of Figure 4a). The key mechanism responsible for tunable 253 color can be interpreted from the perspective of the non-radiative process and surface effect. In 254 present systems, the R/G ratio is mainly associated with two non-radiative (NR) processes: 2H11/2, 255
4S3/2 → 4F9/2 (NR1, ~3600 cm -1) and 4I11/2 → 4I13/2 (NR2, ~3500 cm -1). As presented in Figure 4c, 256
the NR1 process directly transfers the population at 2H11/2 or 4S3/2 to red-emitting level 4F9/2, while 257 the red emission could be indirectly facilitated via the NR2 process and following energy transfer 258 (ET) or excited state absorption (ESA) process from intermediary level 4I13/2 to upper state 4F9/2. 259 Considering that above energy gap could be conveniently compensated by the energy provided 260 from hydroxyl group (-OH), the possibilities of NR transitions and R/G ratios are greatly affected 261 by the amount of hydroxyl group attaching in the surface of samples [34]. To detect the 262
surface-covered functional groups, the FT-IR spectra of YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ samples with various 263 morphologies were recorded in the range of 400 ~ 4000 cm-1 (Figure S5), in which the stretching 264 vibrations of O-H (broad band at about 3380 cm-1) and the characteristic IR-absorption of Y-F 265 (maximum bond beyond 400 cm-1) were observed in all samples [35]. Based on the surface effect, 266 smaller particles with bigger specific areas would be attached with more functional groups, 267 resulting in a small increase in the O-H vibration absorption intensities from truncated octahedron 268 (~1.5 µm) through 2D hexagonal plate (~250 nm) to rice-like particle (~70 nm) [36]. Furthermore, 269 the enhanced lifetimes of green and red emissions in YF3: 1%Er 3+/5%Yb3+ samples with 270 increasing size and morphologies indicated a higher rates of NR process in smaller samples, which 271 provided another strong evidence for the dependence of NR process on particle sizes, as 272 demonstrated in Figure S6. Therefore, the NR possibilities increased in the order of 3D truncated 273 octahedron, 2D hexagonal plate and rice-like particle, leading to the increase of R/G ratio and 274 tunable UC emission color of YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ samples. As well-known, parts of absorbed energies 275 would be converted into heat by non-radiative decay process, indicating that samples with higher 276 NR possibility and weaker UC emission would generate more internal heat [7]. The laser-induced 277 heating of YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ samples with different morphologies were evaluated using an infrared 278 thermometer (Figure 4d). As rising the time of laser exposure to 180 s (P = 100 mW/mm2), the 279 temperature of three products increased rapidly and then leveled off gradually, and the ∆T 280 (thermal variation) were observed to be 9.7, 12.1 and 19.3 K for truncated octahedron, 2D 281 hexagonal plate and rice-like products. As depicted in thermo-images (insets of Figure 5d), the NR 282 rate related heating ability boosts with the decrease of particle size, which are consistent with 283 above results. Considering that heat dissipation ability does influence the sample temperature to 284 some extent, the photo-thermal effects of truncated octahedral micro-crystals with same size and 285 shape but different organic functional groups were investigated in Figure S7. After heating 286 treatment at 500 oC, most of organic functional groups attaching in the surface of samples were 287 removed, leading to the decreased rates of NR process and the R/G ratio. Remarkably, the 288 laser-induced temperature truncated octahedral products without further heated was higher than 289 that of heated samples with removed functional groups, indicates that NR process is a dominant 290 pathway to generate heat and seriously affect the final temperature around samples under lower 291 NIR excitation density. Optical microscopy equipped with a tightly focused 976 nm laser was 292
employed to provide further insights into the UC luminescence of morphology-correlated 293 individual YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ particle. The dark/bright field UC emissions of obtained samples with 294 different morphology were shown in Figure 4e, in which the UC emission intensity increased with 295 the growth of particle size and emission colors were consistent with that of ethanol-dispersed 296 samples (inset of Figure 4a). However, the single particle UC luminescence of the rice-like and 2D 297 hexagonal products were not clearly distinguished because their sizes are too small to achieve the 298 UC emission at single-particle level for the present equipment. On the contrary, intense green UC 299 emission could be obviously observed from a single and intact YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ particle with 300 truncated octahedral 3D micro-architecture. Above results further reveal the perfect morphology 301 and luminescent homogeneity of YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ samples, which are identical with SEM and 302 spectral results. 303

4. Conclusion 363 In summary, uniform YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ nano/micro-thermometers with various morphologies have 364 been prepared via a hydrothermal method without any surfactants. Rice-like (~70 nm), 2D 365 hexagonal plate-like (~250 nm) and truncated octahedral (~1.5 µm) products were obtained by 366 using the stoichiometric amount of NaBF4, NH4F and the excessive NH4F (NH4F/Ln 3+ = 3.5), and 367 the possible formation mechanisms were also proposed. Pumped by 980 nm, the R/G ratio sharply 368 decreased from 1.05 (rice-like particle) through 0.41 (2D hexagonal plate) to 0.30 (truncated 369 octahedron) and UC emission color was finely modulated from yellow to pure green, which was 370 further visualized by single-particle luminescent images. Through monitoring the heating behavior 371 of three samples, higher rate of non-radiative process was responsible to larger R/G ratio in 372 rice-like particles according to surface effect. The thermometric capacities were also assessed 373
though the temperature-dependent UC emission (2H11/2, 4S3/2 → 4I15/2), and the maximum 374 sensitivity of rice-like, 2D hexagonal plate-like and truncated octahedral products was stable and 375 calculated to be about 0.0025, 0.0026 and 0.0026 K-1 at 490 K. Comparing with results from 376 infrared thermal camera, rice-like nano-crystals provide accurate and reliable thermometry in ex 377 vivo experiments. Results imply that YF3: Er 3+/Yb3+ nano/micro-crystals exhibits perfect and 378
stable thermometry at sub-tissue level, which endow it a bright future in biological applications. 379
